sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a reaction involving liquids
message_1:
Calculate the standard enthalpy change for the reaction: 
C2H5OH(l) + 3 O2(g) → 2 CO2(g) + 3 H2O(l), given the following standard enthalpies of formation: 
ΔHf°[C2H5OH(l)] = -277.69 kJ/mol, 
ΔHf°[CO2(g)] = -393.51 kJ/mol, 
ΔHf°[H2O(l)] = -285.83 kJ/mol.
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change for the reaction, we can use the formula:

ΔH°(reaction) = Σ ΔHf°(products) - Σ ΔHf°(reactants)

For the given reaction:

C2H5OH(l) + 3 O2(g) → 2 CO2(g) + 3 H2O(l)

The standard enthalpies of formation for the products are:

ΔHf°[CO2(g)] = -393.51 kJ/mol (2 moles)
ΔHf°[H2O(l)] = -285.83 kJ/mol (3 moles)

The standard enthalpies of formation for the reactants are:

ΔHf°[C2H5OH(l)] = -277.69 kJ/mol (1 mole)
ΔHf°[O2(g)] = 0 kJ/mol (3 moles) (since O2 is in its standard state)

Now, we can plug these values into the formula:

ΔH°(reaction) = [(2 × -393.51) + (3 × -285.83)] - [(-277.69) + (3 × 0)]

ΔH°(reaction) = [(-787.02) + (-857.49)] - [(-277.69)]

ΔH°(reaction) = -1644.51 + 277.69

ΔH°(reaction) = -1366.82 kJ/mol

The standard enthalpy change for the reaction is -1366.82 kJ/mol.
